comments.text: This confusing branding is nothing new for Nvidia and their 60/60 Ti tier GPUs. I'm sure most of us remember the GTX 1060 6GB vs 3GB controversy from back in the day, as a matter of fact, I believe the 3GB variant was reviewed by this channel. I actually own a GTX 1060 3GB (as part of my collection, not in daily use) and in my experience it isn't (or at least, it wasn't) a terrible product because the price was very reasonable. If we go even further back, Nvidia had two distinct versions of the GTX 560 Ti - one with 384 shaders and one with 448 shaders. The 448 shader version had slightly more VRAM, as well. There was also a 2GB version with 384 shaders. The GTX 560 / 560 Ti were incredible value products for their time- capable of playing preexisting games at 1920x1080 with over 100fps, and in some instances at 2560x1440 with 60fps or higher. If you go even further back, you'll discover there were multiple versions of the GTX 260. The original release had 192 shaders and 896MB GDDR3 VRAM. There was an updated version with 216 shaders- and an OEM version with 1792MB VRAM. All of these examples, in my opinion, are more egregious than what Nvidia is doing with the RTX 5060- not that I am trying to excuse their behavior. The truth is, Nvidia gives us less for our money with each generation's 60 series GPUs. The GTX 260 was considered "high end" in its day, and the 216 shader version could perform very similarly to the more expensive GTX 275, and to a lesser extent the GTX 280. Two GTX 560 Ti's in SLI could outperform a single GTX 580 and had an MSRP of $249 vs $499 for the GTX 580- so an SLI setup could, in some instances, be better value for money. The GTX 1060 doesn't even support SLI (yes, I know, it a "dead" technology yadda yadda yadda) but it sucks to remove features all the same. Anyway, I guess I'm saying this entire situation is many years in the making so I'm not particularly surprised.

comments.text:
As you said, Nvidia does know pretty well. There's a reason the 3060 12GB is the most used GPU according to Steam. Given that, it clearly shows how little they care about us in all this. It's not a stupid company. It's just a too greedy company. The only slightly good thing, here in Europe, Greece in particular, I ordered the 5060Ti 16GB for 500 which means, "only" 70 above MSRP. Acceptable. It's fine, really. The new GDDR7 VRAM is an extremely welcome feature with 28Gbps effective speed. 

Now, imagine this card with a little wider memory bus width than the narrow 128bit. It could easily be the best seller of all time, after only the simple '5060' purely for economic reasons. Yet, they opted for 128bit process, which is cheaper to make and ultimately, still will bring them more money than selling more GPUs with wider bus. They rely too much on the uninformed user, unfortunately. This indicates the embedded, malignant DNA of the company.

comments.text:
1. Raw Performance vs. Long-Term AI Investment
You're right that AMD RX 9000 series, especially the RX 9700 XT and RX 9800 XT, are offering very competitive raw performance per dollar right now, especially in rasterization. Thats why people are hyping them up against cards like the RTX 5070 or 5060 Ti  those newer NVIDIA cards dont look like big generational leaps in traditional performance.

But here's the catch: NVIDIA isnt playing just the "raw power" game anymore. They're going all-in on AI and software-defined features like DLSS 3, Frame Generation, Reflex, RTX Video Super Resolution, and possibly more to come. This is where your point shines:

We cannot see performance of actual games. Nvidia can still win in the long run.

Exactly  it's about future-proofing, and NVIDIA has been laying the groundwork for that for years.

2. DLSS vs FSR  Hardware-Accelerated AI Matters
DLSS is backed by dedicated Tensor Cores, while AMDs FSR (even FSR 3 with frame gen) is software-based and doesn't rely on AI in the same way. That difference may not matter as much today, but as games become more graphically intense and rely more on AI-driven upscaling and frame synthesis, the lack of hardware acceleration could become a serious bottleneck for AMD.

DLSS has already proven itself in games like Cyberpunk 2077 and Alan Wake II, where it can massively boost performance with relatively minimal visual compromise  something FSR cant always match.

3. Game Development Trends
Game developers are starting to design with DLSS 3 and Frame Gen in mind  particularly in ray tracing-heavy titles. This trend favors NVIDIA cards even if AMD's raw specs look stronger on paper. If devs optimize more for DLSS (and less for FSR), that will amplify NVIDIAs lead.

4. Longevity Argument
In 23 years, its very plausible that NVIDIAs AI ecosystem will scale better with newer game engines and rendering pipelines. Thats what happened with the RTX 20 and 30 series over time. DLSS matured. Games added support. Suddenly those cards aged better than people expected.

So TL;DR:
Yes, AMD has a current price/performance edge in raw rasterization.

But NVIDIAs long-term bet on AI, hardware-accelerated features, and deep developer partnerships might pay off in a bigger way over time.

If you're planning to keep a card for several years, the value of DLSS, Frame Gen, and future AI features could absolutely outweigh the raw performance gap seen today.

comments.text:
Excellent coverage!

Really glad that you did all of the quality presets in at least some of the games.

The 1% lows, the feel of the game (frametime issues), and the lowered texture quality mean those settings are just not usable on 8Gb cards.

I think that 8Gb cards are 1080p cards or Medium quality setting cards, or both. Depends on the game. Even if the GPU itself is fast enough for 4k.  Too bad the price doesn't reflect that, i.e. if it was a larger price difference, I could see the point in making the 8Gb models if the price was like half..
I don't recommend xx60 tier cards ever, unless price is the deciding factor...  

Agree with your price/vram points.

In the future when we know the performance is going to be shit, it would help to always include a low quality preset test run, so anyone who really has to end up buying one because of the price, knows what the various games' playable settings at least are.  That in comparison to 1440p and 4k test results gives everyone the clear picture of what they gain by choosing the 16Gb cards.  Even the occasional comparison to the 90 class cards would be interesting to include for at least one of the tested quality settings/resolution combinations.  Highest one is fine for that, so that the test results can be used in multiple reviews.

Thanks for taking the time to test these so thoroughly.

comments.text:
Just tossing it up here as a final edit for visibility, your timestamps and gameplay show Final Fantasy XVI (16) but your voice-over and on-screen graphic shows XIV (14). I perked up when I heard it and then went "wait a minute, that's not FFXIV" as a player with over 6,000 hours in that game  it makes little difference as the stamps and game-play performance data are correct, just something I noted. 

$700 for an 8GB 60-class card. Oh yeah, they're trying to get out of the market with this launch or are so detached from reality we'll probably see them on the next Blue Origins flight. There should not be a card in the market with less than 12, maybe less than 16GB VRAM, even if it ends up being the previous gen of VRAM (GDDR6X vs GDDR7), but especially not at these price points. An 8GB model could be viable in a 50-class card at maybe the $150-200 range for AIB models, but not in a 60-class card at this price. The problem for NVIDIA is they positioned the rest of the stack wrong, so they could only have a screwy 60-class card at the bottom. The 90 being at such a high price with 32GB followed by the enormous gap to the 80 with 16GB of VRAM itself (should have been 20 or 24), and so on down the line, does not set them up for a proper distribution in the market. It's either bad decisions by management, or, as suggested, they're trying to move out of gaming so they can allocate their entire node production to ML/AI, even though its demand is shrinking and will kill off their brand in the end if they decide to go this route.

comments.author: @johnWick-lu3ev

comments.text:
@johnWick-lu3ev Swapping so much of the data constantly between the memory bus and the VRAM has a performance cost. Also, small amounts of data can leak into system memory from the VRAM when you run out, which gets worse the more you spill over your VRAM capacity. System memory is much slower than VRAM, introducing latency and worse performance

Show me a single review that doesn't correlate with the information presented in this video
comments.author: @Merp9

comments.text:
@ try looking for other comparison, the thing that you mentioned can only improve FPS by 5 to 15 FPS at most you get max FPS if the game or the games setting max out the vram. having more vram you'll get higher minimum FPS stable frames eliminate maxing out the vram that cause lag or freeze. try watching the video you'll see that the gpu speed and wattage is lower compared to 16gb we are talking about same gpu with different Vram size.

so, this test is BS it's either the 8gb is faulty or the tester manipulate the result.

comments.text: The minimum video memory ram capacity for video cards should already be 12 GB for entry level 1080p resolution gaming and 16 GB for 1080p maximum performance. Any gaming GPU hardware that has less than 12 GB of memory should be relegated to non-gaming programs, legacy software prior to 2024, and gaming software that utilizes 720p resolution or lower output. If anyone desires to utilize output for resolutions beyond 1080p such as 1440p and 4k resolution settings, memory capacity must exceed 16 GB because the processing work involved is more than four times that of the level at the 1080p resolution setting which means even at 32 GB of memory, you are not maxing out the potential output.

Meanwhile, my 6GB Radeon 280x sitting in a box in my closet, laughing at this joke of a GPU. I can't wait for AMD to come back and eat Nvidia's lunch in the low end market. comments.text:
The 5060 ti was sitting at 30 fps on the last of us part 2(a vram HOG) at 4k with very high settings while only using 80 watts of electricity... AND half the power used by the 16GB model.. that's so little it barely even needs a power supply connected, the mobo by itself nearly provides enough power to run this card. A ryzen 7700 matched up with this would use less power than an original ps3. 

yes this card will not play new games at ultra settings and high res... but its the bottom tier card you can get.. It's not supposed to... 

Also, the current gen consoles are vram limited too, and given the market and lack of games on console itll will probably be a few years more before we see the end of the current consoles having games made for them, you also have the handheld PC market is also taking off, so until those dont have games made for them anymore, this card will be very viable. 

The price to performance is worse than the 16GB version yes, but if im A) building my first pc and cant afford much, or B) im trying to make a low power usage system, then it doesnt make sense to get a more expensive version. I suppose you could buy the 16 gb one and power limit... although that seems like a waste of money when you could just buy the cheaper card?

and yeah, dont get me wrong the card is overpriced.. but like... theyre all overpriced..? the 5090, the 9070 xt... even intel's card is kinda overpriced. thats kinda the big problem currently though? 

their most expensive one was always the "best" deal anyway... well depending on what they deemed the "best" thing is when they release it... same idea as buying in bulk... "the more you spend the more you save" - some sleezy GPU salesman

comments.text:
People really don't understand Vram at all. Two identical cards should perform EXACTLY the same (give or take a few frames due to silicon). Often the 8gb card is shown to be running okay yet the 16gb is still running much faster, you just need to look at it's Vram usage.

I see comments saying 8, 10 and 12gb cards are still fine, and I thought my 3080 was doing okay until I got my 4090 and realized that games wanted more Vram even if the 3080 still ran them. There's always something going on behind the scenes, whether it's assets not loading in properly, or at all, or more Ram and Disk usage, that's all best case. Worst case, your game crashes, or is at single digit framerates.

comments.text:
It's pretty much the same across all tiers. Regardless of how many times serious reviewers flat out say a GPU offers bad value or just say things like a 5090 is disgustingly expensive, every generation those bad value products fly off shelves and sell out shockingly fast. 
These type of consumer behaviour is a big part of what allows Nvidia to carry on with their shenanigans and keep it being just "business as usual". 
At this point, unless gamers are shopping for the most expensive GPUs or they actually intend to play games which are only available on PC, if you factor in bad optimization on games, plus Windows poor state as an OS, they're most likely better off just getting a console, even with their caveats. 
At least with one of those they're sure games will work and the system itself will last a generation with a lifespan greater than that of a GPU generation.
comments.author: @felipeavlopes

comments.text: Favoritism maybe?
comments.author: @Morristigue

comments.text: Consoles suck more than Nvidia. And Nvidia sucks too. @felipeavlopes
comments.author: @cameronbosch1213

comments.text:
@cameronbosch1213 They're far from perfect but at least the games released for them are guaranteed to work and not made to excede what their hardware can handle, unlike what happens on PC. 
On PC you can have ports which are originally from the same console generation, having completely polar opposites in terms of specs, meaning your not really old GPU that worked well with game A, will not work so well with game B, yet on the same console those and any other title released during the lifespan of the machine will run. 
And even though the payed online subscriptions suck, at least on consoles you don't have to bother with Windows, which sucks far more than any console you can think of. 
And if you're someone on the more budget/entry level side of the fence, PC gaming is looking worse and worse.
comments.author: @felipeavlopes

comments.text: @felipeavlopesGuaranteed to work on consoles is a literal overstatement. They often don't, and when they do, they don't look much better than the Xbox One or PS4 era.
comments.author: @cameronbosch1213

comments.text:
@cameronbosch1213 Overstatement is saying that they often don't work, when they kind have to, unlike on PC, where far more games remain broken. 
And about the visuals, it's funny that you mentioned it because currently the situation on PC is people will have a 1000 dollar 4K monitor and a high end GPU but will be using upscaling because crap like RT is still a long way from being implemented in a functional way. 
Then you have the lower resolutions, where the Upscaling crutch you shrink down render resolution at times to something even lower than PS3/Xbox 360 output, before blowing the image up. 
Also it's good you specifically touched on the PS4/Xbox One as reference for the visuals because when those were current, an old PC (like a 1st gen Core i5 old) with a GTX 1060 would beat either console, yet nowadays, the entry level GPUs sure as well won't be a better experience than what a PS5 can give you. 
It's silly how a game that's essentially a PS4 game (TLOU 2) at its core will use close to all the VRAM available on the 8GB GPUs. 
I've used both Computers and consoles for games at various times, and sometimes the peace of mind the "dumber" device provides is sorely overlooked. 
You have an awful lot more examples of broken games on PC than on consoles, because the target demographic is larger, which would mean some extemely expensive and disastrous results for companies. 
On the PC side M$ can do whatever and keep making the most widely used OS worse and worse, because they don't really give a damn and on the GPU side Nvidia also does whatever it sees fit and people continue enabling this crap.

comments.text: @despairdx that could be anything from a 12 year old i7 to a 14100K. I think they're trying to say Intel was stuck at 4c/8t for a long time, but with those chips, over a 5 year span there was improvement. With the 5060Ti 16GB model, they're finally surpassing the performance of the 3070 - from 5 years ago. 5 years ago was Intel i9 10900K. It gets absolutely wrecked by the Ultra 7 265K. For AMD that would be comparing the 3950X to a 9800X3D or even a 9700X. In all cases, the gains seen by CPUs over the last 5 years, including core counts to some extent, greatly exceeds the gains seen in the mid-tiers of the GPU market. Usually a 70 series from 5 years ago would see pretty good performance gains going to a new 60 series card. There's some RT benefits, but as far as raster is concerned, it's pretty similar. The RT still isn't stellar and while playable, is also weak enough that again within this generation it will struggle if you want an immersive RT experience.,

comments.text: Nvidia is TRYING to FORCE people to spend hundreds of dollars a year on GPU upgrades... No thanks. Jensen said in a previous investor meeting that he wants the average selling price of his GPUs to be $600, the same cost as a games console, he said. I think this is why every card below $600 is a VERY compromised experience. Nvidia does NOT want you buying $200-$400 GPUs any longer; they want you to spend more so they gimp VRAM, memory bandwidth, performance, etc. to force you into a higher tier than you were previously comfortable with paying for. I hope their strategy fails but I do not have hope as the uninformed masses are the bulk of the Gaming GPU division's sales in the form of prebuilt PCs. I will run my 6800XT into the ground and then buy another AMD GPU for the best value/VRAM ratio I can find at that time. Texture quality is EVERYTHING when it comes to game presentation, in my opinion. Adequate VRAM is a MUST for me.

comments.text:
@ 4 Minutes, 51 seconds there is an important setting that I noticed. You are running those 4060s on PCIe 2.0. As far as the memory capacity is concerned, I would always like as much capacity as possible. However, there is a difference between capacity and speed. The funny part about that, Speed can almost be swapped for capacity. It definitely has to be fast enough. Those new cards are not using DDR6 or DDR6X which was the fastest. They are using DDR7. Which does make a difference. 
   The funny part about many of the newer cards is the fact that they many are running PCIe 8x, which can really only be done with cards that have smaller demands, or cards with exceptionally fast memory. So my opinion is that that 8Gb card is not already obsolete as soon as it was released. It will however be interesting to see how far it will go considering memory capacity demands are going up.

comments.text:
I am gonna have to let my "Stockholm Syndrome" talk... Realistically ~I actually am about convinced everything said in this video is "the truths" there are no "ifs", there are no misleading, nothing is intentionally obscured. Also for a first time @ a rather late stage of my overall life and gaming "career" (since it`s purely a hobby and it only costs money) I have a real life job and that indeed leaves you with a lot less time to enjoy PC so it kind of makes you doubt "the entirety of it"... but what I can say is that at this point... If you need to decide to obtain 8 GB V ram of Nvidia product rather than 16 over 50 or even 70$ even I am wiping for you. It`s a decision you make for lots of time ahead given the circumstances and "PC" is something you want >now< optimally rather than later, but having yourself that "nerfed" over this amount of money put on the overall price is more than sad. It`s tragedy. 
 But I've promised I'll let "the Stockholm Syndrome" talk. I will need some disclosure I am usually not willing to go for, but it is as it is... See 2 years and some months ago I did an entire PC swap... I went from a very old AMD CPU (can put it into model numbers, but won`t, but it was 6 real cores at least, even if slow, old and with tiny l1,2,3 catch) 32 whatever ram (I mean smacking 2 ram sticks when it comes to it is easy at any point, It actually could have been 16 I am surprisingly unsure but it`s likely 16, but again very old very slow), Had an SSD after my HDD sustained a critical malfunction due to reasons and needed new storage unit, so might as well been SSD and... probably the newest and best part inside (admittedly the CPU was bottle necking it) GTX 1650ti (that`s 4 gigs for ya). Being on a PC that old... made me completely stop following PC hardware news, they'd only tilt me. So when I saw myself with a fairly hefty sum of money (for me, but mid in reality) available for PC... I went to the PC shop and have said "Gimme PC for money X" (I've shared this story times and again, but it`s how it goes). Than happened a few things. First I didn`t know we are on the verge of 40 series or I were subconsciously assuming they will be hell of expensive (it were slightly post Scalpers Farm times, that much I knew). The only demand I had... well were 2 demands... And here is 1 more separate circumstance... ever since way back when I just have 2x 1080p@60hz monitors which obviously are still the last thing for me to replace and especially when I didn`t have the hardware power to run anything larger... I still don`t. You might be catching my drift at this point... but I am pretty bum... first I weren`t working and me generally living was sort of miraculous in retrospect... 2nd I am in a 3rd world country where everything luxurious costs for us way more than you feel it, because we are supposed to grow tomatoes and goats for the rest of the people to eat while they play on their super nice PCs and <not> play on PCs of our own. So back to my 2 demands... they were A) be on Nvidia... B) Have an additional HDD for storage reasons. The guy just asked 16 or 32 gigs of RAM within that budged and I said 32, considering whatever that is the realistic minimum actually for me (I am a messy user and I open up a bunch of stuffs of those 2 monitors and in the background while gaming rather than "pure game"). Than he handled me a list... I noticed the two things that were worth noticing... Intel CPU (which I admittedly didn`t even understand naming correlation to grade at that point, but I will stress that at that <same point> any CPU I purchase of that time would be better than the one I used to have in regardless). Turned out later on (after I once again <post factum>, because very smart that way :P, became interest in PC hardware) the guy did sell me god honest top tier <<<for my budged>>> current times (2 years ago) Intel Chip (which I am practically in love with because I am stupid and I tend to fall into fan boy realms, rather than actually using it to it`s full potential, I think, and also not understanding AMDs for same money do better performance... but call it what you want it I like my Nvidia with Intel because witchcraft as an argument). The GPU thou... I truly did not know 8 Gigs is so low coming out of 4... I saw 2x Increase over my 4 Gigs that were almost doing it for the game I play, which in spite of all of this disclosure I won`t share, so that they don`t implement it more greedy requirements :P, that btw is a joke and I think if anything it have gotten ~more fair over time since is a massive online world <<that is Absolutely not WoW or FF14 or Guild Wars 2 or Runescape>> and they polish it more often than not. And those 4 gigs were <already> bottlenecked by the CPU I had... so even the Best Chip for that socket (because I even wasn`t on it) might have even by itself improved things by itself. Also... I've never had 70 series... yep... Was and is 3070... it is not even Ti ... I forgot the Ti + it might have tilted things outside of budged... now I won`t go down to "tuner" but for 1 of the options I had to wait, the other one they could just put in... and I didn`t like/want to wait... I have had products of both tuners before and am in a weird way happy of my "return" to my previous "partner" compared to the one of the GTX 1650ti. Now do I start from Rivas... yes... TNT indeed :P. My highest most luxurious (and I might be mistaken on that one) was 8800 GTX (those were the good times :P... not but they also sort of were). Than I had a very odd ball of I think 540 GTX... 540... Than I had 950 GTX (which was by this partner my current 3070 RTX is) than I had 1050 (notice the 40 and the 50 series here) ti from a 3rd partner I used to have products of (but on laptop and of the AMD side o_0) and than the 1650 ti... So me thinking 3000 generation was the current highest (somehow ignoring the fact 4000 cards exist or just assuming they are way out of my league)... Seeing that 3070 (with it`s in fact only 8 gigs option, so it`s "worst" trait is not being the ti variant) made me feel as if I am touching the Lord by the balls sack. Was all with the desired budged with my first ever purchased windows as well :P. If i knew however how little 8 gigs were even back than... I would have pushed the budged (I could) for V ram alone with either higher 30 series or well those 4060tis I didn`t know of... but in a way I am also glad I didn`t... You see... Actually on 1080p the 5060ti is the first improvement over that 3070 (and I am not talking about those games I will most likely never play, I am talking about the games I do play)... I am pretty sure 3070, even the not TI is slightly faster than 4060 (maybe ti, maybe not) under nearly all circumstances 8 to 8 gigs (from reviews on this site and others like it) and well the 16 gigs 4060ti might and will perform better under <some> 1080p circumstances than 3070 8 gig, but in the end of the day... is "just 60 tier card" and also at this point >of an already old generation"... So what happens now is... all of you somehow current and potential 5060ti 8 gigs variant... you are finally having a faster product than at least the 3070 (and it`s ti variant I am pretty sure). What is it good for thou? Well... for being better than mine... In that particular game I play... everything you do will feel and be better under any circumstances... LoL (that is definitively not that game) caps out on 240 @ nearly all realistic hardware that plays it, but here`s another knowledge drawn by pipe smocking and brujah rituals... Your 240 FPS will be more and Faster and <winning> (if you have better gaming skills than me that is) than my 240 FPS (you also will gonna have to have faster CPU as well...) You also will have better "luck" in TFT. 
 Now me personally I am gonna grit my teeth and do an attempt to go for 5070 and a ti (I am unsure if my CPU will be enough and if it isn`t I will be pretty sad, but I am marginally certain it will hold)... I also will be going for 1440p curved alongside it. Btw... did you know in LoL increase in monitor size and the curve... throws of your entire game because of skill shots aiming and things on screen travel time and cursor "required" to be traveled distances and speeds? It does... Believe it or not... Actually as bad as it sounds smaller monitors are <better> for competitive titles since they are <made and designed> for them... No joke no meme... it is something to be used to when size increase can be afforded and desired... But on true "edge" gameplay not because of FPS that is more or leas easy in LoL (outside of my stated Brujah shenanigans), but because of other crap ton of BS... monitor size increase in regardless if it is with appropriate resolution and FPS scale... degrades in game performance... It`s good for like "adventure" titles with flashy graphics that you go trough ~once... like Indiana Jones or something. But one cannot simply "just play lol"... I mean I have never played cyberpunk 2077 even thou I am pretty sure I can do it on my current rig... I just don`t want to purchase it... have it as size on my SSD and give the time to go trough it... But if you are a fresh gamer hooked by and on LoL... I don`t think ending up on 8gigs GPU if it is 5000 60 series ~stop you from doing so ~unlike me. Just do it :P. But in the end of the day do attempt for the 16 gigs if it have to be the 60 series or Nvidia... Just totally be unlike me and and somehow make the leap to 9070 XT and forget about all of it.

comments.text:
Year: Low-end / Midrange / Flagship VRAM

2011: 0.5gb / 1GB / 2GB
2014: 1GB / 2GB / 4GB (PS4)
2017: 2GB / 4GB / 8GB
2020: 4GB / 8GB / 16GB (PS5)
2023: 8GB / 12GB / 24GB (Pand emic)
2026: 12GB / 16GB / 32GB
2029: 16GB / 32GB / 64GB (PS6)
2032* 16GB / 45GB / 84GB (Moore's Law)
2035* 32GB / 48GB / 96GB
2038* 32GB / 64GB / 128GB (PS7)
 
 
There's a doubling every 3-5 years, outside of external factors, like Pand emic or Chip Shortage.

*predictions

comments.text: There shouldn't be any games that cannot run just fine with 8GB of RAM, it is just lazy or incompetent coding. You can fit 33 different 4k 32bit framebuffers into 1GB of video RAM, that leaves 7GB for textures and any frame should use way less texture memory than that. Even if you double the number of framebuffers, there is still 6GB texture memory left, which should be plenty and if it isn't, the engine should detect that and load compressed or lower resolution textures instead of trying to read them from system RAM. Devs should be forced to develop games on GPUs with max 6GB of RAM, perhaps then they would actually optimize their code instead of just enabled TSAA or some other temporal antialising/upscaler.
comments.author: @AllanSavolainen

comments.text: can I just say something really quick? I'm not trying to "defend corpos" or undermine the fact that the 5060 Ti should have had more VRAM, because it should. comments.author: @EpsilonChurchRVB

comments.text:
@EpsilonChurchRVB He used footage of the 16gb 4060 ti vs the 8 gb version to show the difference multiple times, it's one of the first things in the video. The difference is exactly the same: much lower performance, stutters and horrendous 1% lows. Moreover the difference between the 5060 ti and the 4060 ti isn't that much, especially when we consider that the 5060 ti is 10% slower than the 4070. I distinctly remember reviews of the 16 gb version mentioning how the 4060 ti performed better than even the 4070 in cases where 12gb wasn't enough, which nowadays isn't that much of a distant future. So yes, the difference is massive. Another thing you should keep in mind is that when the 4060 ti was released, 8gb was a bit more acceptable, and most reviewers didn't have the 16 gb version. Now that reviewers have more VRAM hungry games to highlight the difference they won't really go back to reviewing the 4060 ti. If you want you can look for reviews that focus on the differences between the two versions.

In my country the 4070 was well over 200 dollars more expensive, and there is no used market either. I bought my 4060 ti for 550 dollars, which is basically MSRP. I just checked and the 4060 ti is now at about 700 dollars, while the 4070 12gb is at about 1000. The 5060 ti is at about 750 dollars. So while the argument that the 4060 ti is bad value holds in the US where there's a used market and stuff isn't subject to dozens of different taxes and tariffs, this is not the reality everywhere. My 4060 ti is proving to be incredible value for the money, there's nothing it won't run and it has more than enough memory to deal with any game, upscaling and frame generation, and all in addition to the extensive 3D rendering I do where the memory amount is very, very useful.

comments.text:
AMD needs to cancel any plans of a 9060XT 8GB, and preferably "unlaunch" the 9060. Just rename it 9050XT, give it 8GB, and price it dirt cheap.

Also: While I prefer around 90FPS for single player titles, because I'm a mouse player, I have recently tried my buddy's setup. He has is PC hooked to a 48" 120Hz TV and plays from the couch with a controller at a viewing distance of about 3 meters.... The weird thing is that because the panning is so slow with a controller 45FPS + FG looks and feels perfectly fine. This was a really big eye-opener to me, and instantly explained why opinion seem to differ so wildly on what "valid testing" should be. There really are two separate "standards" here.

This means that if you're in the controller + TV category, the problems with 8GB is even worse today, and will bite harder and sooner in new games. And sorry for the stereotype bias here, but controller + TV players are even less likely to be highly tech savvy people who have been around PCs for decades.

comments.text:
Watching the video I noticed that very often the 8 GB version is drawing significantly less power than the 16 GB version.

E. The Last of Us, 4K
8GB: 100% GPU Usage, 2797 MHz, 98.4W, 40 FPS. 2.46 Watt/FPS
16GB: 100% GPU Usage, 2979 MHz, 143.1 W, 76 FPS. 1.88 Watt/FPS.

That's 45 fewer watts or 35% less power, and somehow demanding more power to draw a frame.

Final Fantasy 14, 1080p Natuve, Ultra Preset
8GB: 100% GPU Usage, 2805 MHz, 78.6 W, 33 FPS. 2.38 Watt/FPS
16GB: 99% GPU Usage, 2805 MHz, 136.1 W, 49 FPS. 2.77 Watt/FPS

That's 57 fewer watts or 42% less power, but it IS more efficient at drawing a frame.

Horizon Forbidden West, 4K
8GB: 100%, 2818 MHz, 66.8W, 12 FPS. 5.6 Watt/FPS
16GB: 100%, 2805 MHz, 154.2W, 67 FPS. 2.3 Watt/FPS

That's 87 fewer Watts or 57% less power, but it's still managing to use 2.4 times as much power to draw a frame.

And many other games are similar.

I'm surprised that the GPU is pegged at 100% at full frequency while drawing so much less power. 

It seems like the GPU is close to idling, judging by power draw, so why the frequency and percent usage?
comments.author: @MrMartinSchou

comments.text:
Just to make it clear, I agree that the 8GB model is turd, especially at this price point, however, I don't agree that it'll be a major issue in three years time.
There's still 3.5 years before the next generation of consoles is coming out, and the current generation uses a variance of the 5700 XT, which only has 8GB VRAM. Games are still predominantly designed for consoles, and for good reason; it's standardised, because there's just no way to design games based on PCs that can be using a GTX 1030 all the way to an RTX 5090, meaning, games are still designed to be perfectly playable with 8GB VRAM. No, it's not going to be the best quality, and no, it's not going to give you a "wow" experience, because consoles don't offer the best experience in the first place.
Furthermore, even after the new generation of consoles come out, there's a two-year gap where new games released are still playable on previous generation consoles, meaning there's at least a solid five years before 8GB will "become an issue," and that is assuming the next generation of consoles will have a GPU with more than 8GB VRAM (I'm certain they will, but until it's announced, it is still an assumption) and even then, it's not going to be an overnight thing, especially when games require time to be developed, and even more so for AAA games that utilise this much VRAM.

Point is, yes, I agree this is a dog turd product at this price point, but no, I disagree that it's such a big issue, especially in the next three years.

And before anyone argues with, "consoles are different," I am very aware of that. Consoles don't have external influences like a PC, and their system is designed to optimise performance, therefore 8GB VRAM on consoles is not exactly the same as 8GB VRAM on PCs, etc etc, but the comparison is just gaming, at which point the difference becomes less prominent. If you're going to argue with, well, I'll also be doing this and that on a PC that utilises a portion of the VRAM, then it's not a fair comparison to begin with. Bottom line is, for purely gaming, the differences aren't THAT big between 8GB VRAM on consoles and on PC, and the 5060 Ti is a much faster GPU than the 5700 XT, so it's going to mask a lot of the differences to begin with.
comments.author: @DanteLovesPizza

comments.text:
Dude, it's not about 8GB isn't enough in 2025 or even 2030 at all (for not all people play the newest new stuff! At max settings at 8K!!!" ). As a qualified I.T. guy, I'm confident that 8GB will be enough even for the 2030's for most consumers, no problem. Just look at the limitless amount of games created in the last 20 years  It's reasonable to argue that the processing power of the current generation of graphics cards is enough to run the greatest games of the 2000s, 2010s and even 2020s and 30s with acceptable quality. I had my doubts and thought that it's still good for 1440p DLSS Quality at high settings or a few mediums and low RT, but you convinced me that 8GB is not fit for modern gaming, especially not if the 16GB version might some day only be $30 more. HOWEVER, Steve, I feel the testing in this video *focused*(!) on scenarios people wouldn't buy this card for and you do this a lot. If I'd check the percentage of time that 4k benchmarks were shown in this video versus the RTX 5090 review, this video might win, because the 5090 review had more 1440p time than 4k time. And really - as you show yourself - this video didn't need this, the 1080p medium results say it all, the existence of this card doesn't make any sense. There was no need to go "4k RT" testing as a not-sidenote or Space Marine 4k-texture pack only (without the default textures even tested) in here or rely heavily on Last of Us Remake which is known for its VRAM needs even at pure rasterization.
You guys are my favorite hardware channel and I respect your opinionatedness even if it often doesn't align with my opinions, but this skewing and cherry picking and not looking at things from both sides evenly at first before making the point is pretty crappy.

comments.text: but it's GDDR7 which gets you a lot more out of that 128, look at the 16GB variant results on that 128 bit bus. Yea, it looks cheap and embarrassing on a spec sheet, I agree. Yet, look at the chip and what a huge part of that chip are the interconnects all around the edge. For the smallest die sizes in the line-up there is a balance to be struck between shader core die space and interconnect die space or you end up with a weaker performing product. The real question is, why are there 8GB and 16gb variants, if nvidia could have gone with 3GB modules and had one card with 12GB. I can only assume that the high demand for 3GB modules would outstrip current supply on the market as these chips are still a bit newer than the 2GB modules nvidia uses on all 50xx cards.

comments.text: Might be worth testing what games that are recent and future games that are acceptable at "high" settings for the year and game aspiration, and whether that high setting sits lower than 8GB. Because almost every game IS visually nearly identical at high settings compared to ultra, the only difference you see in image quality for better settings is if you turn up the texture quality. So for games, do they work well if set to texture quality "High" rather than "Ultra" (or one step down), and does that fit in 8GB of VRAM, and can you put almost everything else on Ultra and still get it in 8GB (sans Ray Tracing, DLSS and FG). If a game does, then it is fine for use in 8GB cards, and "High" can be used as the general default image setting as a "one-click" setting. If it looks too "old gen" or still doesn't fit in 8GB at "High" general setting, then the game or card is not 8GB friendly.

comments.text: @124thDragoon The crypto bubble really had nothing to do with the 3060 release as it was planned to have 12 GB well before the crypto surge that happened right around it's release. The reason it has 12 GB is because of it's bus width. A 192 bit bus meant that NVidia could either release a 6 GB card or a 12 GB card. 6 GBs was judged to be too low for the 3060 due to competition from AMD and the fact it wouldn't outperform their previous models so they went with 12 GBs.

comments.text:
Ignoring their antics around Ada and Blackwell generations in general, Nvidia have been scummy for years now; and releasing both an 8Gb and 16Gb version of the same card underlines this. If they had released the 5060 at 8Gb and the 5060 Ti at 16Gb only, there'd be absolutely no valid complaint here at all.

The underlying fact that gets ignored all the time these days, something we always accepted for decades (even HU did, and made videos about it), is that you tailor your settings and expectations for the hardware. And an xx60 tier product is something previously never considered for 1440p let alone 4K, beyond esports titles. Pushing ray tracing and ultra settings on a product which cant handle it is absurdly dumb, something HU would balk at previously.

Last gen, the 4060 was Nvidia's entry level/budget gamer/low end offering. And the 5060 is no different. They can clock this one higher and add the 'Ti' suffix, but its still the lower end of the product stack. 
Just because the prices are absurd these days, doesn't change the fact that these are not products for targeting 1440p or 4k gaming as far as Nvidia is concerned.

comments.text:
"Very capable of 4k" when reviewers have spent 2-3 generations years shitting on faster 80 and 90 gen cards at 4k.

Calling it 4k when it's actually 1440p used to be the exact kind of hypocrisy reviewers like yourselves called out at every turn.

The bottom tier has always been fresh e-waste, with poor resale and low 'futureproofing'.

You should absolutely use your platform to tell people not to buy it, or buy a used AMD or Nvidia instead for less, given that DLSS & FSR work with 6+ year old faster cards just fine.

But you've spent a fair few years sawing through the branch you're now trying to stand on.

As someone who uses my GPU primarily for VR, this tier simply isn't good enough to even pretend to run anything but beatsaber and equivalent experiences that can run natively on an Oculus quest.

But if you gave me the VRAM limitation, I would turn down textures and not enable ray tracing that the card doesn't have the performance to run anyway and call it a day.

This is the same amount of VRAM as a 1080, which I would still be happily using if I was just gaming on a flat screen.

Fundamentally, you're just crying that "cheaper card = slower" as though this is a new and exciting phenomenon.

comments.text: Yeah this thing is trash and shouldnt be bought, but i have to disagree hard on the basis of dont let anybody tell you its not a 4K card. If its not doing 60 on high no RT with no upscaling in new demanding games its just flat out not a 4K card and financial priority wise somebody isnt helping themselves by buying a 4K monitor when the best they can afford gpu wise is a 60 class. All that adds up with the rest of the price of a PC. The card can do some games at 4K with 16 gb for sure with dlss or a few settings turned down but it has ZERO legs. Thats really my only complaint here and its that i think chasing 4K is pointless unless you have a lot of disposable income, 1440p looks damn near just as good on most normal sized desk monitors. Theres no reason why this card shouldnt have atleast 12gb of vram and frankly a bigger bus but i really hate that 4K argument, its a 1440p card at best not just because of vram but also because its too slow for the near future even with upscaling. Its the sane logic for why you wouldnt wanna buy the 8gb version even now for 1080p, it has no legs for the future

comments.text: I do think GPU reviews have become seriously flawed in their methodology. It's all well and good cranking the settings up so that they'll break a slower GPU, but that's not how most people will run it. I recently upgraded to a 5070 and genuinely can't tell the difference in game performance or fidelity between than and my old 4Gb RX570. There undoubtedly are (there are some obvious improvements in Jedi Survivor - the RX570 shouldn't even run it, but it does), but for 1080p gaming, most of the games I've played show minimal improvement. Personally, I think we need a different type of review. One that focuses on the available graphical enhancements that a higher cost GPU provides, over raw performance, because it's tied to that improved performance. What differences can people expect to see?

comments.text:
Under regular loads, the 8GB should compare against the 16GB model much like the RTX 4060 Ti pair.  Wherever the RTX 4060 Ti 8GB would fail, so would the RTX 5060 Ti 8GB.  The real case for further performance degradation from being 8GB is a bloated feature set.  With DLSS and Frame Generation, you need an extra pool in VRAM to handle the upscale processing and frame generation.

What makes this bad is that the high end cards should be running at 4K native quality.  The 5060 Ti and 5060 should be the big user of upscaling tech and frame generation, because they lack the power to handle true 4K processing.  But, said features need to fit their program into the GPU and share space with the game and other applications that may use the GPU at the same time.

This asks the question, how did these games run on the RTX 4060 Ti 8GB and RTX 3060 8GB with and without DLSS and FG?  Why?  Because Nvidia is pushing more AI features on each series and the older models don't have the features introduced on the next generation, does the prior 8GB model that lacks the support for said features run a little better?  This can mean that Nvidia's drivers are getting worse each generation due to feature bloat.  The hypothesis, the driver for the RTX 5060 Ti loads the AI feature set even though the game doesn't support it, occupying VRAM.  Meanwhile for the RTX 4060 Ti, the driver loads fewer features to VRAM, and the RTX 3060 Ti has even fewer features to load.

Having a list of features looks good on paper, but they require space in RAM and VRAM to work.  The more features you have taking up space in VRAM, the less VRAM for the scene being rendered.

The real problem is lies in the general specifications for the "6" Class card in comparison to the price bracket.  For both Nvidia and AMD, their latest "6" class cards all have 8x PCIe lanes, 4 GDDR Memory controllers "128-bit bus", and roughly 32 CU or 36 SM with Radeon CUs being equivalent spec to Geforce SMs.  This is true for RX 6600 XT, RX 7600 XT, RTX 4060 Ti, and RTX 5060 Ti.  The RX 9060 XT is looking to follow this path as well.  This is literally what stagnation looks like.  Why aren't AMD and Nvidia planning on a bigger "6" class GPU?  Is there some natural metric that gravitates to these specs?

comments.text:
I still have my 1080ti running 1440p games smooth as ever. I'm more a simulation player (CIV6, Cities Skylines, Transport Fever 2, The Sapling), so I may have a different mileage. My other card is an RX 6700 XT, which performs slightly better at times. I bought the 1080ti new at launch, must be the best return on investment ever. The Radeon was a lucky find, an open box offer for EUR 250 about two years ago. I've spent maybe EUR 20 on cooling paste since I got the 1080ti, that's it. 
Don't fall into the trap set by Nvidia, if you're looking for a decent card to play 1440p games in 2025 a used 8GB 2080 Super, 12GB 3060 or 12GB RX 6700 XT can be had for EUR 200/350. That will keep you going for another year or two. 

Or go wild and buy a used Mac Mini M1 or M2 with 16GB unified memory. They can be had for about EUR 300/450 and they perform very well in 1440p gaming. You don't need to limit yourself to Apple Silicon native games, there is WHISKEY; the Apple Game Toolkit. Steam will probably runnative on Apple Silicon in the near future, or you can install another Linux distro and download Steam from there. 
The fun thing with Apple Silicon is that they depreciate a lot slower than PC components do. You may be able to sell the M1 or M2 in two years time, for close to what you paid for it. By that time you can get yourself a 5070 for about EUR 300 from people chasing the 7080ti...

comments.text: It makes no sense to release identically named GPUs with such a different performance... unless you want to scam consumer. Logical thing to do would be to release slightly slower 5060 (non-Ti) with maybe 12GB (8GB for any GPU is really bad) and then later release 5060Ti with 16GB.. I also just generally hate how they introducing Ti just right away, I mean sure it is meaningless marketing terms (and I guess that is the problem, why are they meaningless?), but I think in the past there was obvious purpose for that... first they would release 30,40,50,60,70 and 80 cards, then in mid-life refresh they would add Ti once they have enough of them binned for higher clock-speeds and performance and for the market niche where they felt additional performance was needed. SO perhaps they are pressured in mainstream, and in high-end, so rather than cut prices they could introduced better binned silicon at higher clocks, but keep the prices... so we get 60Ti, 70Ti and 80Ti... What they doing now they instead name the graphic cars as such that it give impression that they are much higher grade card than it actually is so they start with 90 (which I guess could be rationalise as replacement for SLI set-up), so we start higher as it is, then 80 and 80Ti (instead of 70 and 80), then 70 and 70Ti (instead of 60 and 50), then 60 and 60Ti (instead of what used to be really 40 and 30).... and to some degree than it makes sense that their 30 has only 8GB of RAM, what doesn't make sense is that they charging ~60 grade card money for it. And then because all this mess is introduced they have to use Super to denote mid-cycle upgrades... or even abomination like "Super Ti". If this isn't only meant to confuse and scam consumers then I don't know what this suppose to achieve?!

comments.text:
At this point I'm not sure if it's bots trying to combat negative press - or - people that genuinely convinced themselves that something that's objectively true and can be proven in repeatable tests somehow doesn't matter.

If it's a problem now already it's definitely not going to get better in future titles and realistically would be $10-20 extra. 
So say worst case $20, and say best case actual MSRP $429 RTX 5060 Ti 8GB. That's less than 5% of the price (4.66%)! 
Realistically at NVIDIAs volume it's probably $10 and I wouldn't be surprised if it's less, and the cards are going for $500+. So the percentage could be something around 2-2.5%.

For those of you would that truly believe 8GB is good enough because you can just fiddle with settings to get the game to run... Don't you think the smart choice is a 2-4.66% more expensive product that just works without fiddling? A product that will a better bet in future products? If you don't - I recommend buying Apple products as well, they have the same sales model.

comments.text:
As someone on an 8gb gpu ( 3070 ) who plays at 1440p , this is disgusting by nvidia , the fact that 2 generations later we're still having 8gb of vram is wild . 

It is true that a lot of games still work well with 8gb , some without any issues at all , and some with minor ones . But undoubtedly it is a compromised experience in many otherd , sometimes u can't use the high textures settings at all or the game will crash or degrade performance , sometimes you start experiencing stutters and texture loading issues when playing for more than 20 minutes and sometimes u can't enable features like RT despite having the performance for it just because of the vram . 
It's not the end of the world when your gpu is a bit old and has already given you a few years of running well , but a new gpu that's basically instantly compromised is terrible , especially since most people won't know the difference between the 2 versions of the gpu , nor how to tweak their settings to have a good experience .

comments.text: I learned from tech deals and will compulsively bring it up whenever reviewers do PCI express testing, and in this case just because we are testing limited video memory configurations, that the combination of a week or smaller PCI express bus with lower amounts of video memory can have a catastrophic effect on performance. It is when your graphics card runs out of video memory that it starts leaning on the PCI express slot for data transfer for much more heavily. So if you are running an 8 GB 5060 TI on a Ryzen five 5600 G, God help you!

comments.text:
I only just retired mine last year, replacing it with a 4070s. I guess people like me are part of the reason Nvidia is doing this.

They managed to 'get' me this time too. I got the 4070S with its 12gb for 1440p, and so far no problems there, but I since moved things around and there's a 4K TV within an HDMI cables length of the PC so I occasionally use that. I've now discovered that with a current UE5 game (Talos 2) The GPU is quite capable of playable frame-rates (60) at 4k Ultra settings, with DLSS4 Ultra quality, Full RT etc, but only without framegen. Adding framegen pushes it over the limit and it just won't run. Frame smoothing is the least transformative option for me so turning it off isn't a big deal, but still annoying in that it's the first compromise I've been *forced* to make since getting the card. DLSS upscaling is technically a compromise i suppose but that gave actual performance without hurting quality in a way I could perceive.

Not thrilled about what I paid in 2024, but I still feel like it was the least worst option, the premium for jumping up to the ti for 16gb still wouldn't have justified the extended life.
If 12gb is barely enough, 8gb definitely isn't.

comments.text:
It's not so much that 8GB is not enough these days, it's that 8GB is not enough for its performance level. The 5060 Ti's performance falls in between that of the 3070 Ti and the 3080, which had 8GB and 10GB respectively. Those cards already had barely enough VRAM when they launched, if you wanted to play at high resolution and high settings.
Shadow of the Tomb Raider, a game from 2018, already uses more than 8GB at 4K native, max settings. Which is how you could play it, at reasonable frame rates, on a 3070 Ti. At the same time, 8GB is plenty for the RTX 3050, because it doesn't have the performance to play at high setting anyway.

comments.text:
GTX 560 ti in 2011 had the same curse and GTX 1060 3/6GB as well.
GTX 560 ti had 1 GB, 1.25GB and 2.5 configurations (back when AIBs could put whatever VRAM they pleased) and even a separate 448 cores version.
Every shill on Tomshardware told me I didn't need the higher VRAM and that 1GB was more than enough.

Just 2 years later, I had trouble playing Bioshock Infinite on ultra 1080p and Watch Dogs was even worse more so because everyone had low VRAM gpus.
So I bought a Radeon HD 7970 3 GB in 2013 and I had learned my lesson.

I then bought a GTX 1070 8 GB and was happy to see the progress in 6 years. From 1 GB card to an 8 GB.
What I didn't know that Nvidia was going to stay in 2016.

I didn't want to upgrade to another 8 GB GPU again in 2018 in the form of 2070 nor pay 1000 USD for 2080 ti to get more VRAM.
So I waited a year more but 2070 super and 2080 super were again 8 GB GPUs and it was the mining crisis time; reluctantly I bought the 2070 super in 2019.

Prices eventually came down and I got an RTX 3080 ti 12GB in used (really wanted a 3090 24GB) as an interim GPU in 2023 hoping for things to change and they really haven't. 
So, Nvidia is playing this game for a very long time and especially since 2016.
I am still unable to buy a decently priced card for 3440x1440 resolution. Even a 16GB VRAM card is not future proof enough.

comments.author: @baraka629

comments.text:
Most games from a decade ago strongly benefited from more than 4GB of VRAM. A decade ago is 2015 after all, so youre talking modern titles like Fallout 4, Arkham Knight, either Rise or Shadow of the Tomb Raider, DOOM 2016 that Im pretty confident prefers 6GB, games of that nature.

Also, I have a bunch of 32Bit games that suffer greatly from the fact that they cant address more than 3.5GB/4GB of VRAM, like Fallout 3/New Vegas, the older Total Wars like Medival / Rome 2 / Rome not remastered / Empire / Napoleon / Thrones of Britannia 2018 (yes, Im incredibly salty that game has a 32bit limit.) leading to the games outright not working at higher resolutions, or in the case of Rome and Thrones of Britannia displaying all the symptoms of running out of VRAM, including blurry textures, models not loading properly and inconsistent performance, while I still have an abundance of VRAM!
comments.author: @levygaming3133

comments.text:
@levygaming3133 Look up the Nvidia Titan X Techpowerup Review from 2015. There is an extra page (33) called "Do we really need 12 GB?" 

It lists the peak VRAM usage across all tested games and resolutions - let me list them for you. 
(In Megabytes)
AC Unity: 3845
Alien Isolation: 1291 
Arkham Origins: 1632
Battlefield 3: 2108
Battlefield 4: 2981
Bioshock Infinite: 2566
Civ Beyond Earth: 950
COD AW: 7332 (!)
Crysis 3: 1996
Dragon Age Inquisition_ 2563
Dead Rising 3: 4326
Far Cry 4: 3321
Grid 2: 1017
Metro Last Light: 1299
Ryse: 3552
Shadow of Mordor: 5288
Tomb Raider: 1347
Watch Dogs: 4065
Wolfenstein New Order: 1702

So yeah, even back then if your game used way more than the 2GB that Crysis 3 used but looked way worse nevertheless, you were most likely an incompetent studio with craptastic devs. But to make a game today in 2025, that looks worse than a 12 year old game yet demands several times as much resources? Just go change careers bro.

comments.text: People seem to think it's just textures that affect the vram. Not the case. It's also models, terrain and object quality at distance, etc. There's a lot that goes into this stuff so eventually it gets to a point where textures are only accounting for a relatively minor portion of the issue. Complexity of the model under the texture also gets loaded into memory, so the more detail the model has, the greater the hit to memory. People want more detailed games right? Well... this is what you get.

comments.text:
Air density: ~1.225 kg/m

Helium density: ~0.1785 kg/m

So, each cubic meter (1000L) of helium lifts:
1.225 kg - 0.1785 kg = 1.0465 kg


Now, your balloon is 100L (0.1 m):
0.1 m  1.0465 kg = 0.10465 kg lift per balloon

To lift an 80 kg person:
80 kg  0.10465 kg/balloon  764 balloons.

So one question remain. HUB flying off the ground video, when ?

comments.text:
This is... bad. Like real, real bad. Honestly kind of shocked to see the kind of difference on display here. Some difference between diffwrent RAM configurations is of course fine. But this? Not even close. 

As is becoming a GPU launch tradition for me, here's yet another request for GPU makers to get DRAM fabs to make 1.5GB VRAM chips, which would let them put 12GB on the same bus width. 12GB would be mostly fine for this, and would make the 16GB SKU a somewhat reasonable upsell for a bit more longevity.

All that being said, some of your testing here is a bit weird. Epic/Ultra/whatever quality with DLSS Performance is a very strange balance of tradeoffs. You do of course do a great range of testing for a lot of the games here, which I really appreciate - but for the ones where you don't, I'd say there's a strong argument for the one quality setting tested for anything remotely midrange rather being Medium Native or medium/high DLSS Quality. And that of course includes testing for the 16GB SKUs.

Also, I have to say I'm rather dubious about your claims of PCIe 4.0 being noticeably worse for this. Are you actually claiming that this card will more than fully saturate a PCIe 4.0 bus? 'Cause that would be quite unprecedented, and IMO requires some data backing it up. (Oh, and what was that unmentioned PCIe 2.0x8 footage in the beginning of the review?)

comments.author: @RognisVornel

comments.text:
@RognisVornel honestly, living through every major generation, optimisation is generally atrocious amongst most developers today. What studios were able to do with the limitations of the SNES, PSOne, PS2 and PS3 era was phenomenal. It's not longer a priority to optimise across the board. Storage compression is another example.

I mainly game on PC but the resurgence of PC gaming has played a part. However at least the accessibility of the games are scalable - turning settings down or off entirely.

The original Switch might be the last bastion of optimisation with games like BotW and Odyssey looking stunning from an art style perspective.

Another factor is generalised game engines like UE5 and Unity. Many games are understandably built using third part engines. Whereas historically, more than not, most game development teams built in house. Which allows for more tighter optimisations.

But regardless, 8GB VRAM is so small in todays terms. The progression of the tech and comparative cards makes it plain to see.

comments.text:
There's nothing to study. If the full textures don't fit in memory the graphics engine can only do 3 things: 
1. nothing (texture is not loaded and not displayed), 
2. attempts to load a mipmap(these are automatically generated but might be missing too),
3. attempt to load it repeatedly costing frame time (still might not get it).

if it barely fit everything for one frame, the next frame it might not (the camera point of view changed, there's more grass in the corner, a new character appeared on screen). This leads to texture flickering and "pop-in".

All games will show one of more of these behaviors. 
Textures need to fit in memory, there's not much a dev can do about it except give you alternate smaller set of textures to select in the graphics settings.

comments.text: @RealHero101111 Last of Us 2 doesn't have that much texture variety or super high resolution textures. My bet is it's just clever in the way it picks what textures appear often (keeping those on the VRAM) and others that can stay on RAM. Also your traversal through the environment is slow due to the game design itself, giving time to minimise pop-in. Given the game is really well optimised for consoles they most likely had to design a really good texture management system. With clever game engine design you could make limited VRAM and RAM work, the issue is it shouldn't really be necessary, VRAM is cheap and in 2025 game engines should be worried about optimizing other stuff other than that. But thanks to Nvidia and game consoles they are still stuck in wasting time with that.

With a 120Hz 4K monitor, first and foremost youd get the advantage of the higher refresh rate in basic desktop usage, which really gets ignored too much. Youd also get 120+FPS on easier to run and eSports games, especially if you run them at eSports graphics settings (but native resolution).

Another advantage of 120hz at 4K (or any resolution) is that it solves 3:2 pull-down judder, and is the reason that some of the more respectable TV manufacturers started using 4K 120hz panels even before any of the ports could handle 4k120hz.

comments.text:
@AntiGrieferGames It is NOT "an optimization problem". Texture quality is the computationally cheapest way to get good visuals, but you can't make presets that magically matches all combinations of GPU power and VRAM amount:

Radeon VII has 16GB (set as baseline as per Techpowerup)
RX 6600XT has 8GB (104%)
GTX 1080ti has 11GB (106)
Arc A770 has 16GB (107%
RTX 2070 Super has 8GB (107%)

How is a game developer supposed to make a preset that makes any kind of sense here? There is only a 7% spread in computational horsepower but a 100% spread in VRAM capacity. On the Radeon VII and A777 you can run Medium settings with Ultra textures, and it looks pretty good. On the 2070 Super and 6600XT you can run Medium settings with Low textures and it looks muddy.

comments.text: @aurum3747Your post states why consoles don't need the extra ram without acknowledging it. Shared memory means similar bits of data won't be duplicated. On a computer where you have two different memory banks for the parts, similar things will be duplicated that both sides of processing uses (if the GPU and CPU need to keep track of something, both need information in their respective buffer, a console with a shared memory buffer won't have this issue.)

comments.text:
HW Unboxed along with seemingly 3.7k people need to check the dictionary and see what planned obsolesence mean.
How is anyone expecting an 8GB graphics card to chew through 10s of GB of textures and render 4 times the screen compared to a 1080p. 

This is an absolute nothing burger and a stupid video. You want to play new HF games on your 4k monitor, get the 16GB, if you need to run Barbie Horse adventures, get the 8GB one. 

Not every card is made for everyone or to run everything. If you want to shit on nVidia for their BS prices, sleazy marketing, re-releasing old cards just a little boosted as new generation, Sure, go on ahead. Complaining that a LOW end graphics card can't run games in 4k is an argument only morons can get hung up on.
comments.author: @RMDetho

comments.text: @RMDetho It's not priced at the low end, nor is it being marketed at the low end, as the 5060 Ti (the name alone) implies mid to mid-high tier.  This isn't a 5030, after all.
comments.author: @WSS_the_OG

comments.text:
@WSS_the_OG Sleazy marketing and BS prices, I've covered both in my comment and these are completely valid complaints. 
But as a consumer I also have two eyes that can read "8GB" and logically come to a conclussion "Yes, their marketing is crap. This is not meant for 4k or [Insert 2024+ UE5 game]". 

Given the amount of comparisons in this video, all I'm arguing is that the point of making such comparison is stupid.

Also, on the flip side. Games today look barely better than 5 years ago and hideous compared to low settings of 5 years ago, and they all equally run like shit and require absurdly priced graphics cards. That's also a major factor here. If game devs weren't lazy about their optimization methods and smart with resources, we wouldn't need to worry aobut the only graphics cards that can decently run those being priced to what is nearly twice the average month's salary in my country. 

Again, plenty of blame to go around here, and we're all equally having to eat shit at the bottom of this industry. All I'm saying is that the benchmarking an 8GB on 4k is just stupid and besides the point.

These 3070 owners then blamed the Devs for an issue caused by insufficient VRAM which was totally unfair. If you want to blame someone, blame Nvidia for gimping the mid range card you bought, thinking it would be great for years to come. comments.text: @RMDetho "All I'm saying is that the benchmarking an 8GB on 4k is just stupid and besides the point."  I quite like that this was done, to show that underlying CPU die can handle 4K, if given a fair fighting chance with adequate VRAM.  People who bought an 8 GB VRAM GPU years ago are probably okay with having to turn a few settings.  They had 4 years of ROI.  It is important to reveal the shortcoming in an 8 GB VRAM GPU as a new purchase today.  As you said, sleezy tactics by a very, very, greedy company, especially when set against the backdrop of Nvidia not sampling 8 GB 5060Ti variants.  I'll double down and say that's what makes it even more important to show how the 8 GB card performs against the 16 GB card at 4K.  I'll also remind everyone (not picking on you) that is NOT being sold at low end prices, or with a low end product name.  xx60 Ti should mean something in 2025.

If they can't deliver a good product then they should rethink who they should cater to and/or scale down their scope. They obviously care enough to cater to PC gamers though. And in many games PC out sells console sales by a large margin. In fact, I think many studios would lose so much money even if PC sales were not the majority. The fact is it is still is a large percentage and they would be in danger of going bankrupt without PC sales. Xbox is pretty much full on PC porting. Sony is trending in the same way with pretty much every IP available on PC now. There are fewer and fewer exclusives for consoles every year. The only true exclusive platform is Nintendo, but they often deliver polished games so they aren't really relevant to this problem.

comments.author: @blitz44444

comments.text:
@blitz44444 In that content type DLSS is specifically avoided to ensure like for like testing. Thus making it an incomplete data sample. That's not to say it's wrong, but as I established in a prior comment, 4K gamers USE DLSS. To ignore it outright is to go out of your way to make your gaming experience worse.

Every generation of "4K class" GPUs has had the asterisk of DLSS or SLI hovering beside it. The 3080 and 3090 were regarded as the "first true high refresh 4K cards," yet failed to achieve this in 3 year old games like Destiny 2 and Monster Hunter World. Both titles required render resolution tweaks of 1728p and game settings adjustments to hit a consistent 120hz refresh rate. If DLSS was considered okay back then in its lesser CNN form, then it's definitely considered okay now. The general rule of thumb for Nvidia 4K results is to multiply the number by your preference of 1.5x/1.67x/1.9x based on acceptable DLSS quality level. With the transformer model 1.9x performance mode is a very fair and reasonable setting to use, just like HUB did in this video.

comments.text:
A friends son was building a gaming computer a while back and he would not consider anything but a nVidia based GPU because the game he played was working best with nVidia based graphics cards. At the time the only graphics card that fit his bill was the 4060 and he was about to buy a 8GB version. I sent him a few links to videos showing the performance difference between the 4050Ti 8 and 16GB versions and managed to convince him to put in the extra money to go with the 16GB version.

Point is people don't know enough about the cost of having to little graphics memory. My take on it  is that you don't buy a GPU for the games you are currently playing but for the games that you will be playing in a year or two. Back when I bought my current graphics card 8GB was plenty for all games currently on market and it was enough for a couple of years more. It's just now that it has started to run out of memory and then it's well out of GPU power so it's time to let it rest.

comments.text: @operator8014 On the contrary, the games are optimized, they're just optimized for higher end cards. When devs decided to move to nanite, lumen, nav meshes, async compute and ray tracing is when they decided to move them backing LODs and lighting into textures and models to your machine. Games got more expensive without getting more expensive. In place of the dev having to spend money on hardware and power and time they moved all that to our machines. In place of them generating LODs they put nanite and nav meshes in and have you compute them on the fly. In place of them backing lighting they use lumen and ray tracing that taxes your machine in place of theirs. Games are optimized, it's just that today they're optimized for the dev's wallet, not yours.

comments.text:
Star Wars Outlaws can barely consistently hit a stable frame rate on a base 3060 12GB, AT 1080P!

While Stalker 2 can barely break 50 FPS on a 4090... at 4K.

You guys need to understand that VRAM alone isn't even close to being enough for AAA games, even 24GB isn't. As a 3060 12GB owner, if you want to get 4K performance on AAA games, you can't just upgrade your GPU and nothing else. You need to upgrade not only your GPU, but your CPU, your PSU, your RAM, AND your SSD for 4K.

If you want max VRAM at 4K, good luck in 2030 where you need a 3090 in order to hit 30 FPS at 1440p on 'Medium'.

The RX 6800 and 7800 XT BARELY stand a chance against Stalker 2 at 4K. Which is bullshit because both of those GPUs have more than enough VRAM to run that game and it can't even get a stable frame rate with 16GB of VRAM at 4K.

If games had the optimization of Sonic Frontiers and publishers gave their developers ACTUAL time to optimize their code, not only would 8GB of VRAM still be enough, but it would also be OVERKILL for 4K 21:9 inch monitors.

comments.text:
@Traumglanz Your giant message shows only in my inbox. There's this elitist attitude I'm seeing here that 1080p should just not exist, despite 56% of people using it and those people likely all having cards that cost between $300-500 most of the time if you look at the data.

Upgrading your monitor won't just magically make your card 1440p capable and yes I am considering 1440p DLSS Performance to be the bar for capable. You will not get 60 fps at max settings in 1440p DLSS Performance with a 60 tier card in every game, so it doesn't make the cut. They have to do 1080p with DLSS to keep max settings. I even did 1080p DLSS Performance to play Cyberpunk with path tracing on my 2060 Super and even then it was 30 fps. 5060 Ti can do 55 fps or so at 1080p DLSS Quality with better RR model but still, if you start to do 1440p DLSS Performance that will drop under 50 from the extra upscaling load, and Cyberpunk is one of the lighter path tracing titles as its on top of an older game.

1440p starts at about $600 and that's usually slightly compromised versions of 1440p GPUs. To get a solid one it's $800+.

To get an entry level 4k, 4k DLSS Performance card you need to pay $1000 even at MSRP which doesn't exist.

So good 1080p cards being $400-500 is fine.
